citation.article-title: Eubacterium angustum sp. nov., a Gram-positive anaerobic, non-sporeforming, obligate purine fermenting organism.

p.s: Description of Eubacterium angustum sp. nov.
Eubacterium angustum (an.gustum. L. adj., restricted, scanty, narrow (substrate spectrum))
Straight, angular rods, 1.1 to 1.5 μm wide and 3 to 6.5 μm long, older cultures form chains, often clumps.
Non-motile but contains flagella, mostly lateral inserted.
Colonies nonpigmented, flat, circular, and 0.5 to 1.5 mm in diameter.
Gram-positive.
Physiology.
Strictly anaerobic; optimum temperature, 37°C growth occurs still at 18 and 45~ pH range for growth, 6.5 to 10; optimum range, pH 5.0 to 8.2; chemoorganotrophic.
For growth, utilizes only uric acid, xanthine, and guanine, hypoxanthine in connection with uric acid, requires thiamine.
Acetate, formate, CO2, and NH3 are products.
Hydrogen, succinate, butyrate, acetoin, diacetyl, 2,3-butanediol, indole, and sulfide not produced.
Nitrate and sulfate not reduced.
Hydrolysis of gelatin, starch, and esculin does not occur.
No hemolysis.
Catalase, lipase, lecithinase, and urease not produced.
No cytochromes were detected.
Growth not influenced by the presence of 2% bile extract.
Murein is directly crosslinked via m-diaminopimelic acid.
Guanine plus cytosine content of the DNA is 40.3 mol% (thermal denaturation method).
Isolated from sludge of the sewage plant in Göttingen.
The type strain is MK-1 and has been deposited in Deutsche Sammlung yon Mikroorganismen, Göttingen, FRG, under the accession number DSM 1989.
